text: Microsolver to create Vellum constraints during a simulation.

The Vellum Constraints DOP allows the creation of new Vellum constraints
dynamically during a simulation.   It is a microsolver so should be wired to one of the solver inputs of the
.  It can also be wired inside of a

Controls if the microsolver is solved at all.  Can be used to add
    constraints on a specific frame, for example.

How frequently to try and create constraints.   Some types of constraints you wish to create just once, and in this case the On Creation Frame simplifies the setup.   Dynamic constraints you may wish to create less frequently than every substep as creating and destroying constraints will slow the simulation.
Apply the creation rules only on the specified creation frame.
Apply the creation rules once every frame, but not more frequently.
Apply the creation rules every substep.  This has the greatest accuracy, but creating constraints can slow the simulation.
Which frame to create constraints on.

The type of constraint to generate.   This affects the visibility of
    many of the other parameters.   Usually this is set by using the
    appropriate tab-menu macro.
Turns each edge in the display geometry into a distance constraint maintaining that edge length.
Each pair of triangles (or implied triangles if input is quads or higher) creates a constraint maintaining the initial dihedral angle between the triangles.
Creates constraints that consist of both distance on edge and bend across triangle constraints.
Creates constraints that consist of distance on edge and bend between edges.  This bend also includes the twist of the edges, allowing torsion effects.

Creates constraints that are a lighter weight hair constraint.  They are a distance along the edge and the angle between edges. However, they don’t have any twist constraints, so the edges can spin freely.
Pins the specified points to the corresponding point in the target geometry.  The target geometry for a Vellum solver is usually the first input, so it matches the animation, but can be overridden.
Attaches the specified points to the geometry in the third input. They will store their closest point at the attach frame and create a distance constraint tying them to it.

Stitches points within the same geometry together using distance
        constraints. The points do not need to actually be connected by
        geometry.  This is useful for keeping jackets closed or preventing
        pockets from flapping.
Stores the original volume and builds a many-point constraint to maintain it, for each piece determined by the
parameter. The enforcement is global, so squishing one place will expand another, like a balloon.  A

point attribute can be used to scale the effect of the pressure constraint on a per-point basis.  This attribute can be used for interesting inflation effects, but should be used with care as it can also lead to unbalanced forces if the
is near zero on only one side of an un-pinned balloon, for example.
Turns each tetrahedron into a constraint to maintain the volume of the tetrahedra.
This does not include any shear or stretch constraints. Additional distance constraints need to be added to make a proper softbody.
While not a constraint per-se, this edits the

attribute to cause the points to be logically fused into a single point for the solve. However, they will remain independent points otherwise. In addition, this can build bend constraints where edges have become logically fused, ensuring the result acts like a single flat piece.  The
can rewire the welded vertices after simulation so that the geometry appears connected for rendering.

Each point will search for a nearby point that is not a member of its own piece.   It will construct a distance constraint holding it to that point.  This is useful for building systems that automatically glue together by proximity, especially when combined with breaking.

Each point will search for a distant point that is of its own piece, but which it has a straight line-of-sight to.  It will build a distance constraint to that point.  This constructs a large number of toothpick like internal struts that give an object stiffness and volume without the expense of a fully FEM solve.
Turns each tetrahedron into a constraint that attempts to flatten along the direction specified by the
if that attribute doesn’t exist.  These constraints can be created with low stiffness that is animated up during the simulation with
Turns each triangle into a constraint that keeps the triangle As-Rigid-As-Possible (ARAP) by removing any stretching or skewing, according to the specified stiffness.
Turns each tetrahedron into a constraint that keeps the tetrahedron As-Rigid-As-Possible (ARAP) by removing any stretching or skewing, according to the specified stiffness.  If
is enabled, the constraint additionally attempts to preserve volume with a very high internal stiffness but the specified
Creates a constraint that pulls its points back to the original (rest) shape, for each piece determined by the
parameter. This constraint can be used to add rigidity either on top of existing constraints such as cloth, or by itself to create mostly rigid objects that can interact with other Vellum geometry.
Shape Match constraints generally work best with
, and with consistently sized geometry. To generate this type of geometry, you can use a
An effective workflow with this constraint type is to use the
on the simulation output to generate an oriented point per piece, then the
to transform the original render geometry onto these points.  This workflow can also avoid any small deformations if the constraint fails to remain rigid at collision points or pins.
Selects which type of Stretch constraints are used when the

constraints converge to
   their proper stiffness faster than

at higher cloth resolutions,
   but do not support anisotropy via the

, also apply
   a constraint that preserves volume with a very high internal stiffness and
   the specified

constraint functions.  Note that for more control, or if
   experiencing instabilities due to the very high stiffness, you can turn
   this option off and add a subsequent

for a similar, but more controllable, volume-
   preserving effect, at a slight loss of solve performance.
An As-Rigid-As-Possible model that gives good behavior for low stiffness, high stretching configurations.
An As-Rigid-As-Possible model that generally performs better for high stiffness, low stretching configurations like hard solids or cloth.

An As-Rigid-As-Possible model that considers the area or volume of the triangle or tetrahedron when solving, making the stiffness values behave similarly across multiple scales.  This option is usually the best choice for most materials, including organic ones such as skin and muscle.
Controls the type used for the source points for the constraint.

The group for the source points of the constraint.  These are
    the points or primitives that are turned into the constraint or
    are used as the starting half of the constraint.

Distance and bend constraints are usually built on a triangle mesh.
    Rather than forcing the input to be triangulated, it can be implicitly
    triangulated.
Do not triangulate the input implicitly.

Attempt to reverse the triangle splitting so a series of quads
        have a less regular structure.

value for the points.  The mass affects how they interact with
    POP forces and other pieces of Vellum geometry, and how strong the constraints are.
Calculate a uniform value for the

attribute for the points on a per-piece basis,
        as determined by the

setting.  For tetrahedral geometry, the overall volume
        for each piece is calculated then multiplied by the

parameter to find the mass of each piece.
        This mass is then distributed equally across each point in that piece.  For polygonal geometry, the overall
        area of each piece is used, and for polylines the line length is used.
Calculate a varying value for the

attribute for the points.  For tetrahedral geometry, each point
        accumulates 1/4 of the volume of each incident tetrahedron to find its overall volume, which is then
        multiplied by the

parameter to find the mass for each point.  For polygonal geometry, each point
        accumulates its share of the area of each incident polygon, and for polylines its share of each incident edge
        length.  This approach generally gives the most physically accurate results, especially as the resolution of
        the geometry changes.
The volume used in calculating mass is scaled by this value when
.  This value can be further set to

to scale by the specified
    point attribute in the varying case.
parameter will be scaled by this point attribute.
Thickness of the points, stored in

.  Used also for the
    triangle thickness and curve thickness.
Calculate a uniform value for the

attribute for the points on a per-piece basis,
        as determined by the

setting.  The thickness value is based on the average
        length of the edges in each piece, scaled by the

parameter.  This setting
        generally avoids excess self-collisions while maintaining uniform thickness.
Calculate a varying value for the

attribute for the points.  The thickness value is based on the average
        length of the edges connected to each point, scaled by the

parameter.  This setting
        is better for geometry of varying resolution, but generally gives non-uniform thickness values.
Each edge length will be scaled by this value before being used in the

Pressure constraints split the object into disjoint pieces to compute and
    enforce the volume. Mass and Thickness calculations, and Glue and Strut constraints
    also need a way to define separate pieces.
This integer attribute’s unique values are used to define each piece.
Connectivity of the input geometry is used to define the pieces.

Distinct values of this integer attribute will be used to define
    different pieces.  This can either be a point or a primitive attribute.
The points will be given this as their

attribute, useful
    in cloth simulations to define a stacking order for Layer Shock.
The type of group for the constraint targets.
The target group.  This group specifies the second half of

For Attach to Geometry constraints, the SOP attached to the third
    input will be read at solve time to get the current animation data.
    Specifying a path here will override that. This is useful if a different
    animation is desired at solve time than capture time.
This is the path to override the animation with, and does not affect the actual capturing. Capturing is always done with the third input.

attribute and sets it to this value.  This
    scales the drag of the point when wind forces are applied to it
    in the normal direction of its surface, or perpendicular to the
    curve.
Differing normal and tangent drag is essential for flapping flags.

attribute and sets it to this value.
    This scales the drag of the point when wind forces are applied to it
    in the tangent direction of its surface, or tangent to the curve.

Points to pin to the target animation.  Usually the target animation is
    the first input of the Vellum solver, but it can be overridden on
    the
How to pin the point position to the target animation.
attribute is set to zero, making the point a hard constraint.  However, as no original value of
is stored, it isn’t possible to release this constraint later.
to make the point a hard constraint.
is unaffected so a POP operation can restore the dynamics of the point later by resetting
A zero length distance constraint is made between the point and its target location.  The Stretch
values are used for this constraint.

In addition to holding the location of a point, for hair the orientation
    often may also be constrained.
This constrains the orientation of the out-going line segments of the hair.  So orientation-pinning the tip of a hair will not affect the angle of the incoming hair.
Do not constrain the orientation to the target animation.
Use the position constraint rules.  In case of Stopped, the
attribute is set to 3 to reflect both types of update are suppressed.
Add a bend/twist constraint to maintain the orientation of the pinned point to that of the target animation.  The Bend
values are used for this constraint.

Controls if the target is updated from the animation during the solver or if only the initial
    value is used.

When finding a matching point to a source point, do not go through
    the target points in order, but pick the point that is closest first.

constraints, do not just choose the closest point,
    but the closest position on a primitive.  The primitive number and
    barycentric coordinates are then stored.  For

constraints, only polylines, triangles, and
    quads are supported as the
for constraint generation when this option is enabled.
Maximum distance to consider eligible for stitching points.

constraints, the attachment point of the constraint
    will slide across the target surface at this rate, where 1 matches the constrained point’s velocity.
    This option only works to slide across primitives, so

.  The method used for finding
    the next closest sliding target can be set with the
A point attribute that scales the

.  This attribute will
    be applied according to the attribute

, and will be stored on the constraint to be
    applied during the simulation.  In this way the attachment point can slide across a painted surface, where the
    painted attribute value controls the

While glue constraints are made between points of different pieces,
    they will only be made between points of the same cluster.   If
    the cluster value is -1, no gluing will be done.
Minimum distance to look for eligible glue points.
Maximum distance to look for eligible glue points.
Maximum number of points to consider for eligible glue points.
The order in which points should be considered for eligible glue points.
You will likely need to increase the

parameter
            when setting this parameter to

, as the internal search function
            always returns nearest points first.  There must be sufficient points in the
            search query to reach the farthest points as specified by the
Number of glue constraints to create for each point.

Each piece has this chance to be marked ineligible for gluing
    and receive and generate no glue constraints.  This allows
    for stray hairs.
Each pair of points has this chance to be being marked ineligible for gluing.
Random seed used to generate the detach chances.

Maximum distance to create struts.   Must be large enough to cover the
    diameter of the object, but avoiding extremely long struts can help
    avoid artifacts.

Struts are created by sending a ray along the direction attribute in
    search of the piece.  The default direction is to use the normal
    of the surface.

Invert the sense of the objects normals for sending rays, useful
    if the incoming geometry has reversed normals.

Verify the goal of the strut has a normal suggesting it was properly
    hit from the inside.

Jitter the direction the strut is sent in to break symmetry in
    the struts.
Maximum number of struts to add for each point.
Chance of a point being marked ineligible for struts.
Random seed to control the jitter and detach chances.

The initial ray for the strut needs an offset to avoid hitting
    the surface it was sent from.

The stiffness of the constraint, which controls how strongly the constraint
    pulls particles back towards its initial rest state.  To dial in initial values,
    change by factors of 10.
Point attribute to scale the stiffness by.

As effective changes in stiffness requires painting over orders of magnitude, this has
    a logarithmic effect.
Single slider control over the stiffness.

As effective changes in stiffness requires painting over orders of magnitude, this has
    a logarithmic effect.

Stiff constraints tend to vibrate or jitter unacceptably.   Damping reduces this by bleeding energy when evaluating the constraint.  Too much damping can prevent the constraint from being satisfied, however.   Values less than 1 must be used.
Attribute to adjust damping, multiplied into the damping ratio.
Single slider to control damping, multiplied into the damping ratio.

The rest length of the distance constraints will be the original distance
    between the points.   This scale can be used to increase or decrease
    this.   Setting to
will try to collapse the points together.

The stiffness of the constraint when being compressed below its initial rest
    distance.  A very stiff low resolution cloth can become unbendable due to its
    topology, rather than due to the bend constraints.  A network of triangles
    has very few ways that it can bend if it is fully stiff.  By setting a
    lower compression stiffness, the cloth is allowed to collapse and regain
    its fluidity.  Usually this has to be raised with higher resolution cloth.

The distance from the rest length at which the stiffness of the constraint
    decreases to zero, or increases from zero to full stiffness, depending on
    the direction of the dropoff.  A

dropoff means that the
    stiffness starts at full strength and decreases to zero at the Dropoff
    distance from the rest length.  An

dropoff means
    the stiffness starts at zero and increases to full stiffness at the
    specified distance from rest length. If

is enabled, its
    value is used as the minimum stiffness in these calculations, rather than zero.

Decreasing dropoff can be useful for creating glue constraints that lose
    stiffness as they are stretched, decreasing to zero at the specified
    distance.  Using the same distance in the breaking

will cause the constraints to be
    removed at the same time they reduce to zero stiffness.
If this checkbox is turned on, this value will be the minimum stiffness used when calculating the

Enables an adjustment to the stiffness based on orientation, allowing
    a cloth network to stretch more on one axis than another.
Scale factor for cloth lined up with the material u axis.   This is a logarithmic multiplier.
Scale factor for cloth lined up with the material v axis.   This is a logarithmic multiplier.
Scale factor for cloth lined up with the diagonal material uv axis.   This is a logarithmic multiplier.
Point attribute to use to specify the coordinate frame for warp and weft computations.

Plasticity allows an object to flow to a new rest position.  Under
    sufficient stress, the rest coordinates are blended to the current dynamic
    coordinates, so the object will retain its new shape.

Constraints that attach to geometry or pin to the target can optionally
    blend in the target’s velocity.  This requires the target to have
    a

point attribute to provide the local velocity.  The blending
    is done per 24th of a second, so a blend factor of 0.5 will mix in
    50% of the target velocity in a standard frame.

Blending in velocity will highly damp the simulation, but can be useful
    to allow the cloth to anticipate motion, avoiding whiplashing from
    sudden movements.   Zero stiffness attachment constraints can be used
    to apply only velocity blending without any additional forces.

Below this threshold the material will return to its original shape.
    When deformed past the threshold, it will begin to creep into
    its new configuration.
Attribute to scale the stretch threshold by.
Single scale slider for the threshold.
The threshold can either be an absolute distance, or be a percentage distance.   A value of 0.1 as a ratio would mean stretching of 110% of compression of 90% will trigger plastic flow.

The speed at which the material adopts its new rest lengths when
    it begins to flow.
Attribute to scale the plastic rate by.
Single scale slider for the plastic rate.

Some plastic materials become stiffer after they've undergone deformation. These will have a hardening greater than 1.  Some become softer so will have hardening less than 1. This is a logarithmic multiplier on stiffness.
Attribute to scale the plastic hardening by.
Single scale slider for plastic hardening.
The generated stretch constraints are all added to this primitive group.  This is useful to edit them later with a
Ensures that a particular point can only be constrained once by the constraints in the

.  When dynamically creating constraints it can be common to re-create constraints between the same points every frame.  Keeping the points unique within the output group prevents a constant accumulation of constraints.

When welding points together, two outside edges may become an inside edge.
    If they do not gain any bend constraints the seam will be weak and
    noticeably fold or kink.  This option generates bend constraints where
    this is detected.

The value of the generated bend constraints can be copied from the bend
    of surrounding triangles, ensuring a consistent piece of cloth is
    built without having to channel link parameters.

The stiffness of bend constraints.  To dial in initial values,
    change by factors of 10.
Bend constraints are based on angle differences, so higher resolution cloths will require higher stiffness to exhibit similar radii of curvature.
Very high bend stiffness on high resolution models will require a very large number of iterations to converge.
Point attribute to scale the stiffness by.

As effective changes in stiffness requires painting over orders of magnitude, this has
    a logarithmic effect.
Single slider control over the stiffness.

As effective changes in stiffness requires painting over orders of magnitude, this has
    a logarithmic effect.

Stiff constraints tend to vibrate or jitter unacceptably.   Damping reduces this by bleeding energy when evaluating the constraint.  Too much damping can prevent the constraint from being satisfied, however.   Values less than 1 should be used.
Attribute to adjust damping, multiplied into the damping ratio.
Single slider to control damping, multiplied into the damping ratio.

The rest angle of the bend constraints will be the original dihedral
    angle between the triangles.   This scale can be used to increase or
    decrease this.   Setting to

will treat the original configuration as a
    flat sheet.

The number of degrees away from the rest angle at which the stiffness of
    the constraint decreases to zero, or increases from zero to full stiffness, depending on
    the direction of the dropoff.  A

dropoff means that the
    stiffness starts at full strength and decreases to zero at the Dropoff
    degrees from the rest angle.  An

dropoff means the stiffness
    starts at zero and increases to full stiffness at the specified degrees away
    from rest angle. If

is enabled, its value is used as the
    minimum stiffness in these calculations, rather than zero.

dropoff can be useful with cloth to make it buckle
    from a flat state very easily, adding additional wrinkling without changing the overall
    bend stiffness and look of the cloth too significantly. Decreasing dropoff can be useful
    for making stretchy glue constraints that weaken right before breaking without snapping back.
If enabled, the minimum stiffness value when calculating

When adding torsion-free string bend constraints, they work best when
    the rest angle is close to straight.  Setting the max branch angle allows
    something like a net of ropes to only have the bend constraints along
    the straight ropes, not on the perpendicular sections.

Plasticity allows an object to flow to a new rest position.  Under
    sufficient stress, the rest coordinates are blended to the current dynamic
    coordinates, so the object will retain its new shape.

Below this threshold the material will return to its original shape.
    When deformed past the threshold, it will begin to creep into
    its new configuration.

This is an absolute angle measurement.  Because rest angles are often
    flat, the idea of a ratio that exists for stretch constraints does not
    apply to bend constraints.
Attribute to scale the bend threshold by.

The speed at which the material adopts its new rest angles when
    it begins to flow.
Attribute to scale the plastic rate by.
Some plastic materials become stiffer after they've undergone deformation. These will have a hardening greater than 1.  Some become softer so will have hardening less than 1.
Attribute to scale the plastic hardening by.
The generated stretch constraints are all added to this primitive group.  This is useful to edit them later with a
Ensures that a particular point can only be constrained once by the constraints in the

.  When dynamically creating constraints it can be common to re-create constraints between the same points every frame.  Keeping the points unique within the output group prevents a constant accumulation of constraints.

Constraint primitives can be removed by the solver when sufficient deformation or stress is applied, effectively breaking those constraints.   You can also manually break constraints by deleting them during the solve to gain full control of the timing.
Running the simulation first with visualization enabled can be useful to find what are good values for the thresholds.
The amount of stress or displacement on a constraint to trigger a break.
Point attribute to scale the threshold by.
Single slider to scale the threshold.
This controls how the solver decides to break weld and hair constraints.
The stretch stress must exceed the threshold.
The bend stress must exceed the threshold.
The total distance from the goal location and the current location must exceed the threshold.
The ratio between the current distance and the rest distance must exceed the threshold.
The difference between the current angle and the rest angle must exceed the threshold.  This value is specified in degrees.
This controls how the solver decides to break distance constraints.
The stretch stress must exceed the threshold.
The total distance from the goal location and the current location must exceed the threshold.
The ratio between the current distance and the rest distance must exceed the threshold.

The scale-by-attribute functions have to apply the possible different scale attribute values on the points involved in the constraint to a single constraint.  This controls how they are blended together.
The maximum scale factor is used.
The minimum scale factor is used.
The average of the points scale factors is used.
The scale factors are all multiplied together.
The source points scale factor is used, such as in a stitch constraint.
The target points scale factor is used, such as in a stitch constraint.
primitive attribute for all constraints created by this node. This tag can be used in the
to easily to alter specific constraints.
Data on the simulation object to use as the source for computing edges, etc.  Usually the display or collision geometry.
Data on the simulation object to add the new constraints to.

title: Vellum Constraints
summary: Microsolver to create Vellum constraints during a simulation.
